notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Synchronous - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Society and culture from various anthropological perspectives: socio-cultural, evolutionary, archaeological, and linguistic.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Anthropology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given online, synchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week (Professor and 2 TAs) to ask questions and clarifications about course content.
Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).
Tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: A course focused on recent anthropological scholarship that seeks to understand and explain the transformation of contemporary societies and cultures. Topics may include some of the following: new patterns of global inequality, war and neo-colonialism, health and globalization, social justice and indigeneity, religious fundamentalism, gender inequalities, biotechnologies and society etc.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.
Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos/week asynchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus.
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours by appointment and per announcements.
Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).
Tests will be held during official classtime, timed and online.
The timed final exam window will take place at a time/date designated by the university.

courses.name: Core Concepts in Social and Cultural Anthropology

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid - See Timetable Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Society, culture, kinship, exchange, community, identity, politics, belief: these and other core concepts are explored in this course, which lays the foundation for advanced courses in social and cultural anthropology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Core Concepts in Social and Cultural Anthropology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online, hybrid course. 

Lectures will be given asynchronously as 1-2 hour online videos/powerpoints with audio recordings for each class meeting. Each lecture will be followed by short tasks/assignments that students must complete on Quercus within 24 hours. 

Students will sign up for synchronous online tutorial sections that will meet once per week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours two times per week. 

Students will need to be able to watch videos and listen to recordings, and will also need access to a microphone or headset. Video capability is optional but strongly preferred for tutorials. 

Tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to applied evolutionary medical anthropology. It explores evidence for the evolution of human vulnerability to disease across the life cycle (conception to death) and implications for health of contemporary populations in gendered cross-cultural perspective.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This is an online course, with synchronous and asynchronous components available and to be completed on Quercus. 
Lectures will be given by the Course Instructor as 2-hour online videos/week, first synchronously in real-time T,R 2-4 PM EST and then available asynchronously as recorded. 
One-hour, Topical Review Clinics will allow for questions and discussion with Teaching Assistants. 
Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Tests will be timed and online. 
Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: April 16, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical field training through six weeks of excavation on an archaeological site. Basic principles of artifact handling and classification. (Offered only in Summer Session) Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeological Fieldwork

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please visit this website for further information on this field course and enrolment instructions: https://anthropology.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/field-schools-research-opportunities/

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: March 24, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides background in the practical and theoretical aspects of fieldwork in Paleoanthropology. Students are trained in the treatment and analysis of fossil vertebrates, plant macro- and micro-fossils and sediments. Excursions to paleoanthropological localities of Homo erectus and Homo sapiens, and excavation at a hominoid site. (Joint undergraduate-graduate) Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Additional fees of up to $2500 for field trip costs will apply.
cmCourseInfo.title: Paleoanthropology Field School

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Please visit this website for further information on this field course and enrolment instructions: https://anthropology.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/field-schools-research-opportunities/

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Asynchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: Social anthropological perspective on the nature and meaning of food production, culinary cultures, industrial food, food as metaphor, and famine and hunger.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Food

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Online Hybrid

cmCourseInfo.description: It is widely acknowledged that sharp disparities in disease burden and access to medical care characterize global patterns in health. These disparities affect the life chances of much of the worlds population, based on class position, gender, and geographical region.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology and Social Justice

cmCourseInfo.description: An instructor-supervised group project in an off-campus setting. Details at http://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/course/rep. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Excursions

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Enrolment for the Research Excursion Program is done by Arts and Science. For more information, please see: https://www.artsci.utoronto.ca/current/academics/research-opportunities/research-excursions-program

cmCourseInfo.description: Supervised independent research on a topic agreed on by the student and supervisor before enrolment in the course. Open in exceptional circumstances to advanced students with a strong background in Anthropology. Course Supervisor must be a member of the Anthropology faculty. Application for enrolment should be made to the Department in the preceding term. A maximum of one year of Independent Research courses is allowed per program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A minimum of 10 credits, permission of Supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Application forms are available at the Anthropology Building located at 19 Russell Street, Room 258. Completed forms must be returned by April 27, 2020. For more information, please contact josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca.
